instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00291: What is 820-00291? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00291</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Greetings to all.

This machine does not have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

Voltajes en <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> 

Pin 12: <SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P12V_S5_SSD</SIGNAL> (3.41V)
Pin 24: <SIGNAL>PM_EN_REG_P5V_S4_R</SIGNAL> (0.00)
PIN 17: <SIGNAL>PP12V_S5_FET_P3V3_S5_P5V_S4</SIGNAL> (12.0V)
PIN 4 y 5: 0V

Pin 5 y 4 it's an LDO which is generated by the same <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>.

I changed it a couple of times and nothing.

I know I must have that LDO first.

no shorts on L7610 or L7650.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00291</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on LDO5 and its coils.
Be sure to get good solders and check all traces too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00291</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00291</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Check solders, traces and all <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> surrounding components.
Be sure to use "C" version of the chip (ISL62383C),

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00291</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Solved, I made a mistake. Pin 12 <SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P12V_S5_SSD</SIGNAL> had no voltage, let me be guided by the voltage that reaches <RESISTOR>R7698</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P12V_S5_SSD</SIGNAL>. I thought that this entered pin 12 of the <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and it is not.

Analyzing well who arrives at that pin 12 is <SIGNAL>PM_PGOOF_FET_P12V_S5_SSD_K</SIGNAL> that comes from the <CHIP>U8490</CHIP>. Heat it up a bit and you're good to go.

Thank you. Apologies.

Thank you [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER]
